Description: Egyptian terracotta female figure wearing hair back in bun, following Tanagra types. Head only. Mould-made and hollow. Traces of white coating on skin and red paint on hair. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably locally produced at the Naukratis terracottas workshop that was operational from the 3rd to the 2nd century BC. Good parallels for the hair style dating to the late 4th and early 3rd century BC from Alexandria (Besques 1992, pl.87, no. D4565). Besques, S. 1992. Catalogue raisonné des figurines et reliefs en terre- cuite grecs, étrusques et romains, 4, 2. Epoques hellénistique et romaine. Cyrénaïque, Egypte ptolémaïque et romaine, Afrique du Nord et Proche-Orient. Paris.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.362) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 84, no. 80, pl. XII, no. 80)
